VEC.Q: How many ridgelines are in this ridgeline chart?
VEC.A: There are {6} slices in this chart.

SRP.Q: What is the spatial relationship of the peak of Wheat relative to the peak of Oats in terms of vertical (above/below) and horizontal (left/right) directions?
SRP.A: The peak of  Wheat is to the {left} of the peak of Oats.

VPR.Q: What distribution pattern does the ridgeline representing Wheat show?
VPR.A: The ridgeline representing Wheat shows a {Single Peak Distribution}.

VPR.Q: At what value do  Soybeans reach its peaks?

EVJ.Q: Which ridgeline has the highest peak
EVJ.A: The ridgeline representing {Barley} has the highest peak.

EVJ.Q: Which label has the highest density at X =702.5?
EVJ.A: At X =702.5,the label with the highest density is {Wheat}

NF.Q: Which countries in the ridgeline chart have ridgeline peaks exceed 2051? Please list the countries and corresponding peak values.
NF.A: {Corn}'s peak at {4084},{Oats}'s peak at {4104},{Soybeans}'s peak at {4114},{Barley}'s peak at {3799}

NF.Q: Which countries in the ridgeline chart have ridgeline peaks below 3570? Please list the countries and corresponding peak values.

NC.Q: Which one has a larger X value at the peak of its ridgeline: Wheat or Barley?
NC.A: {Barley} has a larger X value at the peak of its ridgeline.

NC.Q: Which one has a larger X value at the peak of its ridgeline: Wheat or Rice?
NC.A: {Wheat} has a larger X value at the peak of its ridgeline.

NC.Q: Which one has a larger X value at the peak of its ridgeline: Rice or Soybeans?
NC.A: {Soybeans} has a larger X value at the peak of its ridgeline.

NC.Q: Which one has a larger X value at the peak of its ridgeline: Rice or Corn?
NC.A: {Corn} has a larger X value at the peak of its ridgeline.

MSR.Q: How many ridges have their peak located to the right of the average X value across all ridges?
MSR.A: There are {4} ridges whose peaks are located to the right of the average X value.

MSR.Q: What is the label of the ridge with the largest span along the mountain height?
MSR.A: The ridge with the largest span in the mountain height is {Barley}
